definition: A step-by-step procedure to solve a problem or perform a task.
A way of organizing and storing data for efficient access and modification.
Mathematical notation to describe the time and space complexity of algorithms.
A collection of elements identified by an index or key, stored in contiguous memory.
A linear data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
A linear data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
A collection of nodes where each node contains data and a reference to the next node.
A technique to map data of arbitrary size to fixed-size values, usually for fast lookups.
A technique where a function calls itself to solve smaller subproblems.
A hierarchical data structure where each node has at most two children.
A binary tree where left child < parent < right child, used for efficient searching.
A complete binary tree used to implement priority queues.
A collection of nodes (vertices) and edges connecting pairs of nodes.
Depth First Search, a graph traversal algorithm exploring as deep as possible before backtracking.
Breadth First Search, a graph traversal algorithm exploring level by level.
Arranging data in a specific order such as ascending or descending.
A divide and conquer algorithm that splits arrays, sorts them, and merges them back.
A divide and conquer sorting algorithm using partitioning around a pivot.
An optimization technique that solves problems by breaking them into overlapping subproblems.
An approach where decisions are made by choosing the best immediate option.
An algorithm design paradigm that breaks problems into subproblems, solves them, and combines results.
A state where processes are stuck waiting for resources held by each other indefinitely.
Software that manages computer hardware and provides services for applications.
An instance of a program in execution.
The smallest unit of execution within a process.
A synchronization primitive used to control access to shared resources.
A mutual exclusion object that allows only one thread to access a resource at a time.
A memory management technique that uses disk storage as an extension of RAM.
A memory management scheme where processes are divided into fixed-size pages.
A memory management scheme that divides processes into variable-sized segments.
A small, fast memory that stores frequently accessed data.
An organized collection of structured data.
Structured Query Language, used to manage relational databases.
The process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve consistency.
A unique identifier for each record in a database table.
A field that links one table to another in a relational database.
A database object that improves the speed of queries.
A sequence of database operations executed as a single unit of work.
Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability - properties of reliable transactions.
Different levels of database normalization (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF).
A set of computers connected for sharing resources and communication.
A unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a network.
Domain Name System, translates domain names to IP addresses.
HyperText Transfer Protocol, used for communication between web browsers and servers.
Secure version of HTTP that uses encryption (SSL/TLS).
Transmission Control Protocol, ensures reliable communication between systems.
User Datagram Protocol, provides faster but unreliable communication.
A 7-layer framework for understanding network communication.
A network security device that filters traffic based on rules.
The process of converting data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access.
Encryption technique using a public and private key pair.
A program that translates source code into machine code.
A program that executes source code line by line.
A style or way of programming, e.g., OOP, Functional, Procedural.
Object-Oriented Programming, based on objects and classes.
A blueprint for creating objects in OOP.
An instance of a class in OOP.
OOP feature where a function or object behaves differently based on context.
OOP feature where one class acquires properties of another.
OOP concept of hiding implementation details and exposing only functionality.
OOP principle of bundling data and methods together while restricting access.
Application Programming Interface, a set of rules for interaction between software components.
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data interchange format.
Representational State Transfer, an architecture for web services.
An architectural style where applications are built as a collection of loosely coupled services.
